animalOfTheDay.name: sea turtle
facts: Sea turtles can migrate thousands of miles between feeding and nesting grounds.
The temperature of the nest determines the gender of the hatchlings.
Leatherback sea turtles can dive deeper than 1,000 meters (3,280 feet).
They return to the same beach where they were born to lay their eggs.

calendar.name: sandpiper
facts: Sandpipers are shorebirds with long bills for probing sand and mud for food.
Some species undertake incredible migrations, flying nonstop for days over open ocean.
They perform elaborate aerial displays during courtship.
Sandpipers have specialized bills that can sense vibrations of prey underground.

calendar.name: sardine
facts: They are rich in omega-3 fatty acids and are an important commercial fish.
Sardines swim in massive schools that can contain millions of fish.
They are an important food source for many marine predators, including whales and dolphins.
Sardines get their name from the Italian island of Sardinia where they were once abundant.

calendar.name: scorpion
facts: Only about 25 of the 1,500+ scorpion species have venom deadly to humans.
Scorpions glow under ultraviolet light due to fluorescent chemicals in their exoskeletons.
They can survive for months without food by slowing their metabolism.
Scorpions give birth to live young, which ride on their mother's back until their first molt.

calendar.name: sea cucumber
facts: Some species can liquefy their bodies to squeeze through small spaces.
They play a crucial role in ocean ecosystems by recycling nutrients on the seafloor.
They breathe through their anus by pumping water in and out of their respiratory tree.
Sea cucumbers can eject their internal organs as a defense mechanism and later regenerate them.

calendar.name: sea lion
facts: Sea lions can dive up to 900 feet and hold their breath for 10 minutes.
Sea lions can rotate their hind flippers forward to walk on land.
They are intelligent and can be trained to perform complex tasks.
They are highly social and communicate through barks, growls, and body language.

calendar.name: sea otter
facts: Sea otters hold hands while sleeping to prevent drifting apart.
They play a crucial role in maintaining kelp forest ecosystems by controlling sea urchin populations.
Sea otters have the densest fur of any animal, with up to 1 million hairs per square inch.
They use rocks as tools to crack open shellfish while floating on their backs.

calendar.name: sea turtle
facts: Sea turtles can migrate thousands of miles between feeding and nesting grounds.
Leatherback sea turtles can dive deeper than 1,000 meters (3,280 feet).
They return to the same beach where they were born to lay their eggs.
The temperature of the nest determines the gender of the hatchlings.

randomAnimals.name: red panda
facts: Red pandas are not closely related to giant pandas but share a bamboo-heavy diet.
They are endangered, with fewer than 10,000 left in the wild due to habitat loss.
They have a false thumb, an extended wrist bone, to help grip bamboo.
Red pandas are solitary and mark territory with scent glands on their feet.

randomAnimals.name: barn owl
facts: Barn owls have asymmetrical ear openings that help them locate prey in complete darkness.
They can fly completely silently due to special feather structures.
A single barn owl family can consume over 3,000 rodents in one breeding season.
They swallow prey whole and regurgitate indigestible parts as pellets.

randomAnimals.name: owl
facts: They swallow prey whole and later regurgitate indigestible parts as pellets.
Owls are silent fliers, thanks to specialized feathers that muffle sound.
Their asymmetrical ears help them pinpoint the exact location of prey in complete darkness.
Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees due to specialized vertebrae.
